Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Impacts of maternal environment on milk immunofactors and infant immune system development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In addition to being an infant's first food, human breast milk is medicine. Molecules in milk can protect infants from infectious illness. Recent technological advances now allow scientists to fully explore the wide range of molecules contained in mother's milk. To better understand the sources of variation in the immune protection provided by breast milk, this project will investigate how the mother's current and childhood environments impact the composition of key immune molecules in her milk. This research will also explore how the variation of these milk molecules might influence infant immune system development and consider how the immune system has changed during human evolution. This research has direct benefits to society, including informing parent's infant-feeding decisions, donor milk bank policies, and infant formula composition. This work will also create opportunities for training women and under-represented groups in science through established programs in the US and Poland.

Monthly milk samples will be collected from mothers at the Mogielica Human Ecology Study Site in Poland. This study location encompasses villages with varying levels of participation in traditional agriculture and a cash economy, leading to a unique diversity of environments in a small geographic area. The milk samples will be analyzed in the United States using mass spectrometry for selected immune molecules. Milk composition will then be compared to detailed health history interviews to determine what aspects of the maternal environment most influence levels of immune factors in the milk. To explore consequences of variation in milk composition for the infant, milk composition will be compared to salivary measures of the infant's immune function. This study is unique in its longitudinal design, which will allow the researchers to contextualize variation in milk composition and infant immune function in relation to the environment. This study will make a substantial contribution to the existing biological anthropology literature by expanding our knowledge of how immune factors secreted in milk relate to childhood and current exposures in the maternal environment. These findings not only have public health implications but are important for understanding physiological adaptations to human evolutionary transitions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human milk provides more than just nutrition for infants. It also contains a variety of immune molecules that help protect the infant against infection while its own immune system is maturing. The concentration of these immune molecules in milk varies among mothers. Biological anthropologists think that the types and amounts of immune molecules that a mother produces reflect the pathogens that she has been exposed to over her lifetime. However, while researchers know that milk composition varies among mothers, little is known about how a mother’s environment is related to the concentrations of the immune molecules in her milk. This project investigated how the concentrations of a selected number of immune molecules in milk varied among mothers living in different environments in southeastern Poland.

During the funding period, the Co-PI spent nine months interviewing mothers and collecting milk and saliva samples from mothers and infants living in Krakow and rural villages within the Mogielica Human Ecology Study Site. These locations were chosen because they allowed us to recruit mothers living in different household types with different expected exposures to pathogens. Mothers from Krakow typically live in apartment buildings in densely populated areas (urban households). Historically, households in the rural villages at the Mogielica Human Ecology Study Site engaged in small-scale agriculture. Some households still engage in traditional agricultural activities and mothers in these households typically regularly assist with agricultural chores and are exposed to a variety of livestock and domesticated animals (farming households). However, this area is undergoing a rapid economic transition and many households have one or more members engaged in wage labor and do not participate in traditional agricultural activities (rural households). Mothers in these rural households typically had small gardens and more frequent exposure to small domesticated animals than mothers in urban households, but less than mothers in farming households.

We found that the concentrations of immune molecules in milk such as secretory IgA, lactoferrin, and human milk oligosaccharides varied both among mothers and within individual mothers over time. However, contrary to our prediction, there were not significant differences in the concentrations of secretory IgA or lactoferrin in milk among women living in urban, rural, or farming households. This suggests that overall pathogen burdens may be more similar than expected among women living in these environments. Alternatively, many immune molecules have redundant protective functions and the composition of these molecules together may be more important than their individual concentrations.

The results of this project have improved our understanding of the variation in human milk composition and have particularly added to what is known about milk composition from rural mothers who are under-represented in the current literature. The results of this project also have practical applications. A better understanding of milk composition can help inform donor milk bank policies, such as donor-matching metrics, and contribute to improvements in the production of infant formulas. In these ways, studies of milk composition benefit all families, regardless of their infant feeding choices.

We have begun to communicate the findings of this project to other researchers through invited academic lectures, at professional conferences, and through the submission of manuscripts to academic journals. In order to reach a broader audience, we have and will continue to share our findings with undergraduates, health professionals, the study communities involved in this project, and the general public through lectures, scientific outreach programs, and the PI’s blog.

This project also created training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate women. One graduate and five undergraduate Polish students were trained in collecting biological samples, anthropometric measurements, and conducting interviews as part of this project. This training helped prepare these students for future careers in public health. This project also represents part of the doctoral dissertation of the Co-PI.
